country.name: Nauru
country.background: The exact origins of the Nauruans are unclear since their language does not resemble any other in the Pacific. Germany annexed the island in 1888. A German-British consortium began mining the island's phosphate deposits early in the 20th century. Australian forces occupied Nauru in World War I; it subsequently became a League of Nations mandate. After the Second World War - and a brutal occupation by Japan - Nauru became a UN trust territory. It achieved independence in 1968 and joined the UN in 1999 as the world's smallest independent republic.

geo.note: Nauru is one of the three great phosphate rock islands in the Pacific Ocean - the others are Banaba (Ocean Island) in Kiribati and Makatea in French Polynesia; only 53 km south of Equator

location.desc: Oceania, island in the South Pacific Ocean, south of the Marshall Islands

area.comparison: about 0.1 times the size of Washington, DC

geo.climate: tropical with a monsoonal pattern; rainy season (November to February)
geo.terrain: sandy beach rises to fertile ring around raised coral reefs with phosphate plateau in center

elevation.high: unnamed elevation along plateau rim 61 m

geo.issues: limited natural freshwater resources, roof storage tanks collect rainwater but mostly dependent on a single, aging desalination plant; intensive phosphate mining during the past 90 years - mainly by a UK, Australia, and NZ consortium - has left the central 90% of Nauru a wasteland and threatens limited remaining land resources

people.ethnic-groups: Nauruan 58%, other Pacific Islander 26%, Chinese 8%, European 8%
people.religions: Nauru Congregational 35.4%, Roman Catholic 33.2%, Nauru Independent Church 10.4%, other 14.1%, none 4.5%, unspecified 2.4% (2002 census)
people.languages: Nauruan (official, a distinct Pacific Island language), English (widely understood, spoken, and used for most government and commercial purposes)

capital.time-difference: UTC+12 (17 hours ahead of Washington, DC during Standard Time)

government.administrative-divisions: 14 districts; Aiwo, Anabar, Anetan, Anibare, Baiti, Boe, Buada, Denigomodu, Ewa, Ijuw, Meneng, Nibok, Uaboe, Yaren
government.independence: 31 January 1968 (from the Australia-, NZ-, and UK-administered UN trusteeship)
government.legal-system: mixed legal system of common law based on the English model and customary law
government.suffrage: 20 years of age; universal and compulsory

executive.head-of-state: President Marcus STEPHEN (since 19 December 2007); note - the president is both the chief of state and head of government
executive.cabinet: Cabinet appointed by the president from among the members of parliament
executive.elections: president elected by parliament for a three-year term; election last held on 1 November 2010 (next to be held in 2013)
executive.election-results: Marcus STEPHEN reelected in a parliamentary vote of 11 to 6

legislative.description: unicameral parliament (18 seats; members elected by popular vote to serve three-year terms)
legislative.elections: last held on 19 June 2010 (next to be held in 2013)
legislative.election-results: percent of vote - NA; seats - independents 18

government.parties: Democratic Party [Kennan ADEANG]; Nauru First (Naoero Amo) Party; Nauru Party (informal); note - loose multiparty system
government.membership: ACP, ADB, AOSIS, C, FAO, ICAO, Interpol, IOC, ITU, OPCW, PIF, Sparteca, SPC, UN, UNCTAD, UNESCO, UPU, WHO

representation-in-usa.chancery: 800 2nd Avenue, Suite 400 D, New York, NY 10017

government.flag: blue with a narrow, horizontal, yellow stripe across the center and a large white 12-pointed star below the stripe on the hoist side; blue stands for the Pacific Ocean, the star indicates the country's location in relation to the Equator (the yellow stripe) and the 12 points symbolize the 12 original tribes of Nauru

economy.overview: Revenues of this tiny island traditionally have come from exports of phosphates. Few other resources exist, with most necessities being imported, mainly from Australia, its former occupier and later major source of support. In 2005 an Australian company entered into an agreement to exploit remaining supplies. Primary reserves of phosphates were exhausted and mining ceased in 2006, but mining of a deeper layer of "secondary phosphate" in the interior of the island began the following year. The secondary phosphate deposits may last another 30 years. The rehabilitation of mined land and the replacement of income from phosphates are serious long-term problems. In anticipation of the exhaustion of Nauru's phosphate deposits, substantial amounts of phosphate income were invested in trust funds to help cushion the transition and provide for Nauru's economic future. As a result of heavy spending from the trust funds, the government faced virtual bankruptcy. To cut costs the government has frozen wages and reduced overstaffed public service departments. Nauru lost further revenue in 2008 with the closure of Australia's refugee processing center, making it almost totally dependent on food imports and foreign aid. Housing, hospitals, and other capital plant are deteriorating. The cost to Australia of keeping the government and economy afloat continues to climb. Few comprehensive statistics on the Nauru economy exist with estimates of Nauru's GDP varying widely.
economy.industries: phosphate mining, offshore banking, coconut products

imports.commodities: food, fuel, manufactures, building materials, machinery

telephones.assessment: adequate local and international radiotelephone communication provided via Australian facilities
telephones.international: country code - 674; satellite earth station - 1 Intelsat (Pacific Ocean)

communications.broadcast: 1 government-owned television station broadcasting programs from New Zealand sent via satellite or on videotape; 1 government-owned radio station, broadcasting on AM and FM, utilizes Australian and British programs (2009)

military.branches: no regular military forces; Nauru Police Force (2009)

manpower.notes: Nauru maintains no defense forces; under an informal agreement, defense is the responsibility of Australia
